--- Darren Izzard <zysyshelp@...> wrote:
> 
> >One thing that does bother me though is that to be
> /really/ good some
> >kind of adaptive (e.g. hebbian)network would be
> required. So if for
> >example there was a partial mechanical failure the
> NN could adapt (as a
> >human would) to controling the system with it's new
> dynamics
> 
> How about making the simulation slightly randomised
> as regards the
> capabilities of the vehicle? (ie. Each training run
> would involve a vehicle
> with slightly different acceleration, or maybe a
> wheel not working, or
> something like that.) That way, the network would
> evolve to have a degree of
> flexibility, and determine its capabilities from its
> sensory feedback. In
> fact, if you slightly randomised your physical laws
> too, this might allow
> the network to better deal with the inevitable
> differences between the
> simulation and the real world, when it was placed
> into the vehicle.

I agree with your thinking here, and its true that an
ANN can be evolved that deals with randomness.  In my
thinking about this problem, I had planned to have
randomness in the "boulders".  There would be a random
number of boulders, in random locations, and with
random diameters.  There would also be a user option
for a non-random run.  I had not thought about
randomness in the vehicle characteristics or the
traction of the sand, etc.  All of that is certainly
possible, and could result in a very robust ANN
controller.

This approach might be of great value if you want to
use the controller in a real vehicle.  It means that
the simulation does not have to be as accurate,
because you are covering all bases, so to speak.
 
All of that is done in EvSail, except that the
randomness there is in the wind speed and direction,
and in the boat's starting location.  EvSail succeeds
in evolving controllers that handle this randomness. 
As one might expect, it takes a lot longer than the
non-random case.

=====
Mitchell Timin
http://annevolve.sourceforge.net
